story.text: TORONTO, Jan 3 The Canadian dollar fell hard versus the U.S. dollar on Wednesday as commodity prices turned lower while a slew of market players adjusted positions according to recent economic data after the holiday break. Domestic bonds prices were higher ahead of U.S. data that could offer clues on the direction of U.S. interest rates. At 8:35 a.m. (1335 GMT), the Canadian unit was at C$1.1695 to the U.S. dollar, or 85.51 U.S. cents, down from C$1.1636 to the U.S. dollar, or 85.94 U.S. cents, at Tuesday's close. The Canadian dollar fell as low as C$1.1700 to the U.S. dollar earlier as investors focused on recent U.S. data that suggested the U.S. Federal Reserve may hold rates steady for a longer period than many expected. "The data coming out of the States over the last couple of weeks has been quite good but the market's been in flow mode because of all the holidays," said Steven Butler, director of foreign exchange at Scotia Capital." "Today's the first day that the market's been back to full strength so we'll have to see if we start to get a better feel for what's actually going on in the world." The Canadian dollar was also hurt by a drop in commodity prices as mild weather in the U.S. Northeast shook oil prices and a bout of profit-taking hit gold prices after they came close to a one-month higher. The Canadian dollar often shadows the moves in oil and gold prices since Canada is a producer and net exporter of oil and many base metals. January is expected to be a volatile month for currency markets as it marks the start of a new financial year for most people and many investors are putting off positions. "You don't want to bet the farm on a trend emerging in the first week or two," said Butler. "I think by the end of January we'll probably have a much better feel for how Q1 is going to shape up." BONDS RISE Canadian bond prices were higher, but with no domestic data on tap dealers were waiting to see reports out of the United States as well as minutes from the U.S. Federal Reserve's latest rate-setting meeting. The economic calendar in Canada picks up on Thursday with November producer and raw materials prices, as well as jobs figures for December and the December Ivey Purchasing Managers index on Friday. The two-year bond climbed 4 Canadian cents to C$100.50 to yield 3.976 percent, while the 10-year bond rose 18 Canadian cents to C$99.72 to yield 4.036 percent. The yield spread between the two-year and 10-year bond moved to 5.7 basis points from 6.4 at the previous close. The 30-year bond rose 35 Canadian cents to C$126.50 to yield 4.098 percent. In the United States, the 30-year treasury yielded 4.755 percent. The three-month when-issued T-bill yielded 4.15 percent, unchanged the previous close.
story.title: canada dlr weighed down by commodities , bonds up
